messageBody:
rootsonwings wrote:
> hello !
> some one consider this
>
> public class Adder{
>
> public int add(int a , int b){
> return a + b;
> }
>
> /*
> <test>
> <method name= "public int add(int a ,int b)">
> ... test codes
> </method>
> </test>
> */
> }
> how about this where we have same file for the logic as well as the
> test for it and when it is build let say using ANT we have option for
> excluding the test codes or test it .
> is it possible ?

As Simon indicated, your approach depends on an unfounded assumption,
that each method ought to be tested individually, and there ought to be
some small number of tests per method. Even if this is mainly true, it
is not universally true.

I will add this important point: one of the nice things about xUnit
(JUnit included) is that we write the tests in the same language as the
production code. Your approach breaks this model for no apparent gain.
(Tell us why you prefer to do what you propose over just writing JUnit
tests in the usual way.)

If you want to have tests with the code, I recommend using Javadoc-like
attributes to indicate which test case classes/test suites contain the
tests for each method/class under test. If you are testing behavior that
spans multiple methods, then I don't know what to do... something
reasonable will come up.

Good luck.
